Up at the top is the bit that's supposed to be helpful: it's the 16th
eleme=
nt of the collectEntityAttributes array that's failing.  I'll bet
that woul=
d be much more helpful if it printed the value, rather than
the location in=
 the array.  What do you think?

   David

>> > I've added a feature request, that would at least allow a theory to =
be declared to be run as discrete. =A0AKA:
>> >
>> > @Theory(runAsDiscrete=
=3Dtrue)
>> >
>> > which would generate a new "test" for each combination o=
f parameters. =A0The name of the test would include the parameters (using t=
he toString method on the parameters of course). =A0It may generate 100+ te=
st names, depending on the number of data points and the combinations, but =
that works better for me than one name and one failure at a time.
>> >

knowing what failed, the Theories runner should show in

rin C.
>> > <berin.loritsch@...> wrote:
>> >> I haven't logged the feature =
request, mainly because I might not be using the right tool for the job. =
=A0What I would like to see is what I described.
>> >>
>> >> With JUnit 3, =
I adopted the test nomenclature of something on the order of:
>> >>
>> >> t=
estMyMethod_withNullParam1()
>> >> testMyMethod_withXandYparams()
>> >>
>> =
>> etc.
>> >>
>> >> that would let me see within the test report (particula=
rly a continuous integration test report) what exactly failed. =A0If the nu=
ll parameter failed its check I'd have to fix one thing (boundary checking)=
, but if the XandYparams version failed then I knew something may be wrong =
with the algorithm.
>> >>
>> >> With the particular Theory I've written I n=
eed to know not only the class that was tested, but the attribute that did =
not follow the contracts for using the base class. =A0With only one failure=
 that can't happen.
>> >>
>> >> I didn't think Rules was the right way to g=
o, because the MethodRule objects were applied to the tests within that sam=
e class (unless I'm missing something).
>> >>
>> >> Theories at least gives=
 me the coverage and assurance I'm after, but I'd like to get away from wri=
ting to System.out to figure out exactly what failed. =A0I would also like =
to be able to see all my failures at once instead of only after fixing the =
last failure.
>> >>

On Fri, Feb 5, 2010 at 3:27 PM, Loritsch, Berin C.
>> >> <berin.loritsch@..=
.> wrote:
>> >>> Thanks everyone for helping me work through the testing ch=
allenge I wanted to address. =A0I've written a rudimentary ClassCollector t=
hat lets me specify a base package, what base classes I need, any annotatio=
ns I need applied, etc. =A0I supplimented that with a BeanAttributes class =
that will collect all the attributes (setters/getters) on the class. =A0It'=
s working very well. =A0Unfortunately, there are a few shortcomings with th=
is approach:
>> >>>
>> >>> 1. I cannot easily determine what the actual dat=
a point combination was that caused the failure. =A0I have to write those v=
alues out to System.out because the test failure does not do that for me.
>=
> >>>
>> >>> 2. It stops on the very first failure, hiding many more failur=
es that may still be lurking beneath the service.
>> >>>
>> >>> 3. The theo=
ry is the only line shown in the test report, so there is no way to differe=
ntiate runs which would handle the above concerns.
>> >>>
>> >>> What I wou=
ld really like to see is that a new test name for each combination of data =
points. =A0For example if you had a @Theory named "checkAddWorks" that took=
 two parameters and the data points [1,2] then I'd like to see a set of tes=
t names that look like this in the test report:
>> >>>
>> >>> checkAddWorks=
(1,1)
>> >>> checkAddWorks(1,2)
>> >>> checkAddWorks(2,2)
>> >>>
>> >>> Tha=
t will address all of the shortcomings I identified.
>> >>>
>> >>> My code =
looks like this:
>> >>>
>> >>> @RunWith(Theories.class)
>> >>> class TestMy=
TrackableContract {
>> >>> =A0 =A0@DataPoints
>> >>> =A0 =A0BeanAttribute[]=
 collectAllAttributesToTest() {
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0ClassCollector collec=
tor =3D new ClassCollector();
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0collector.within("com.m=
ycompany.incident.model").assignableTo(Trackable.class);
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0=
 =A0Collection<Class<?>> matchedClasses =3D collector.recurse().collect();
=
>> >>>
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0List<BeanAttribute> attributes =3D new ArrayLi=
st<BeanAttribute>();
>> >>>
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0for (Class<?> trackable :=
 matchedClasses) {
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0attributes.addAll(BeanAttr=
ibute.collectFrom(trackable));
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0}
>> >>>
>> >>> =A0 =
=A0 =A0 =A0return attributes.toArray(new BeanAttribute[attributes.size()]);=

>> >>> =A0 =A0}
>> >>>
>> >>> =A0 =A0@Theory
>> >>> =A0 =A0public void che=
ckSideEffectsOnAssign() throws Exception {
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0// This is=
 designed to ensure that setters/getters work in concert
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0=
 =A0// and that setters set the appropriate message is sent
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =
=A0 =A0if ( ! beanAttribute.hasSetter() || ! beanAttribute.hasGetter() ) re=
turn;
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0beanAttribute.assertBalanced();
>> >>>
>> >>> =
=A0 =A0 =A0 =A0Trackable entity =3D beanAttribute.getEntityAs(Trackable.cla=
ss);
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0// Unfortunately needed to determine when things=
 go bad
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0System.out.format("Testing %s\n", beanAttribu=
te);
>> >>>
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0Object original =3D beanAttribute.getValu=
e();
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0Object testValue =3D beanAttribute.generateTestV=
alue(original);
>> >>>
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0// Ensure the setter works as =
expected
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0beanAttribute.setValue(testValue);
>> >>> =
=A0 =A0 =A0 =A0assertEquals(testValue, beanAttribute.getValue());
>> >>>
>>=
 >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0// Ensure properties are set and events were properly
>=
> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0Properties changes =3D entity.getChanges();
>> >>> =A0=
 =A0 =A0 =A0assertEquals( String.valueOf(testValue),
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0=
 =A0 =A0changes.getProperty(beanAttribute.getAttribute()));
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =
=A0 =A0assertEquals( String.valueOf(original),
>> >>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0 =
=A0changes.getProperty(beanAttribute.getAttribute() + ".old"));
>> >>> =A0 =
=A0}
>> >>> }
